    Vectorized Sparse Encoding

    VSE: Vectorized Sparse Encodings

    VSEs are vectorized encodings of sparse data, and are intended to make two key improvements over conventional sparse storage: 1. Efficiently compress redundant discrete and integral data far more than traditional CSC sparse data structures 2. Vectorize sparse data effectively to reduce time spent iterating over multiple vectors

    VSEs are containers that behave like sparse vector classes, and offer a consistent vocabulary of sparse random access iterators that make it easy to develop generic sparse matrix wrapper classes or other templated containers relying on the VSEs.

    This project is just getting started!

    To learn more about VSEs, check out the package vignette!

    This work is covered under the terms of the GPL-2 v3 license. This work is independent of Sparse Run-length Encoding, a non-vectorized form of discrete sparse data compression, made available under the MIT license in the singlet R package.
